CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 10;Violation of Art. 13+10;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant , a historian , specialises in the functioning of the secret services of dictatorships , comparative studies of the political police forces of totalitarian regimes and the functioning of NORP - type GPE . He has published several works in this field .

CARDINAL . With a view to publishing a study concerning the functioning , in DATE , of ORG of ORG , on DATE the applicant requested the Ministry to grant him access to certain documents deposited with it .
CARDINAL . His request was denied on DATE ; the ORG made reference to a decision of CARDINAL DATE classifying the documents as ORG secrets until CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought an action against the ORG , basing his claim on LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE on ORG and LAW . Claiming a right of unrestricted access to the documents , he submitted that the data he sought were necessary for the purposes of his ongoing historical research .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found for the applicant , granting him access to the documents for research purposes . It observed that the documents in question had indeed been classified during the NORP era . However , according to section CARDINAL ) of Act no . CARDINAL of DATE on ORG , they would have had to have been characterised as such again before DATE . Since this characterisation had not taken place , the documents had lost their classified nature ipso iure by DATE , irrespective of the decision of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the respondent ’s appeal as it had been introduced outside the statutory time - limit .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG proposed access to the applicant if he signed a confidentiality undertaking .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the enforcement of the judgment , arguing that the respondent ’s imposition of a condition of confidentiality was unacceptable . On DATE the enforcement procedure was initiated and an enforcement order issued . In its reasoning , ORG observed that the respondent did not have the right to require confidentiality from the applicant as a precondition to the access granted by the enforceable judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld on appeal the decision of DATE but deleted from the reasoning the confidentiality observation .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE the ORG brought an action with a view to having the enforcement proceedings terminated . On DATE the Pest Central District Court dismissed the action , holding that the respondent ’s proposal of CARDINAL DATE was unsatisfactory and that , therefore , the initiation of enforcement proceedings had been lawful . On CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the ORG ’s appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Ministry issued the applicant with a permit for access to documents , but restricted him from publishing the information thus acquired to the extent that “ State secrets ” were concerned .

CARDINAL . In the absence of a permit granting unrestricted access to all the documents concerned , the court found that there had not been compliance with the enforcement order , and on DATE the ORG was fined MONEY ( ORG ) ( MONEY ( ORG ) ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE all but CARDINAL of the documents were transferred to ORG and thus became public .

CARDINAL . A further enforcement fine of ORG CARDINAL ( approximately EUR CARDINAL ) was imposed on DATE in respect of the CARDINAL remaining classified document . ORG filed an objection , arguing that the document was no longer at its disposal since it had been transferred to ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the respondent ’s objection , holding that a change in the physical whereabouts of the document did not exempt the ORG from its obligation to grant the applicant access .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the ORG ’s request to have it established that the ORG were its successor in the matter .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the decisions of DATE , DATE and DATE , and remitted the case to the first - instance court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again dismissed the ORG ’s request to have it established that the ORG were its successor in the matter . However , on DATE it observed that the newly founded ORG was indeed the successor . On DATE it rejected the new ORG ’s request to have the proceedings interrupted pending the succession arrangements .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the new ORG appeals against the decisions of DATE , DATE and DATE . The ORG ’s petition for a review by ORG was to no avail .
CARDINAL . To date , the applicant has not had unrestricted access to the remaining document in question .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of Act no . CARDINAL of DATE on ORG and LAW provides as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) If an applicant ’s request for data of public interest is denied , he or she shall have access to a court .
( CARDINAL ) The burden of proof concerning the lawfulness and well - foundedness of the refusal shall rest with the organ handling the data .
( CARDINAL ) The action shall be brought within DATE from the notification of the refusal against the organ which has denied the information sought .
( CARDINAL ) The court shall give priority to these cases .
( CARDINAL ) If the court accepts the applicant ’s claim , it shall issue a decision ordering the organ handling the data to communicate the information of public interest which has been sought . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of Act no . CARDINAL of DATE on ORG ( which entered into force on DATE ) provides as follows :

“ The review of the classification of classified documents originating from before DATE shall be terminated within DATE from the entry into force of this Act . Once this time - limit has passed , the documents shall cease to be classified . ”
